text:
When I do these kind
of talks, I usually like to do just one thing. And so I thought I'd focus
on a particular project

called Reach bot. This has been a very
fun collaboration with Marco Pavone and his lab
in AeroAstro and with Matthieu

Lapotre who's in geophysics. And the motivation is that there
are features on Mars, especially

Mars, but possibly
other planets that are very interesting
from a geological history

and an astrobiological interest. And these include
caves and lava tubes. So when you see, for
example, a crater

like this, what
that likely is, it's an opening to a subterranean
lava tube which people

would like to explore. And there is a project
actually called MELT, Martian Exploration
of Lava Tubes,

and they're interested
in several things. First of all, a cave or a
lava tube under the surface,

it's protected from radiation. It's protected from the
extremes of environment. So if there would be
any signs of past life,

that might be a
good place to look that it would still be there. Looking ahead, if we
are going to build

any kind of human habitation
on the Mars or on the moon, doing it down inside a lava tube
is actually a really good place

to do it. Once again, you're
protected from the extremes of temperature, from radiation.

You could seal it off and
have an atmosphere locally. And so there's a lot of interest
in exploring these features.

Well, there's interest,
but it's hard. Here's a lava tube on Earth. This is in the Mojave Desert.

And this is what they
look like inside. This is really difficult terrain
for a wheeled vehicle or even

a legged robot. It's actually not all that easy
even for people to walk around. So we've got steep
and overhanging faces.

And, by the way, it's
the overhanging faces that are especially
useful to explore because they're not going to be
covered with debris and dust.

It's inaccessible. If you're in a thin
atmosphere, flying robots have very poor
manipulation authority.

If you're on the moon,
you can't fly at all. And existing climbing robots
which have been built.

The problem is that
they go very slowly and they require lots
of grasping points. And, actually, we've worked
some of my former students, some

of those 79 at JPL, a state
of the art climbing robot is called LEMUR.

This is LEMUR 3, and it can
go over very rough terrain. It uses microscopic spines.

And I'll talk more about that in
a minute to climb rough terrain. But it proceeds
very, very slowly.

And also there's a risk. It does a tripedal crawl
moving one leg at a time.

If it runs out of graspable
spots, it may be in trouble.

Well, you could make
the robot bigger. Unfortunately, doing that,
making it bigger greatly

increases mass and
cost and complexity.

So here's a wonderful little
GIF that Stephanie Schneider, one of Marco's students, made.

And I play this because it
captures the idea behind the bot as well as anything I've seen.
So we'll just watch that.

And at the end, I think
it takes a selfie.

So that is the concept. So the first idea that
motivated lightbot

is, well, could there be a way
because everything that you launch up into space and land
on the moon or on a planet,

it's very expensive
per kilogram. Could we have a
small robot, maybe

the size of a carry on
suitcase with really long arms so that it doesn't have
this problem of short reach

and moving terribly slowly and
finding enough places to grasp? It's not entirely
an original idea.

we have a very small
body and it can go in very, very rough
terrain on its scale by virtue of these
very long legs.

So that's a good example. What do you suppose could be the
problem with scaling this up?

By the way, and all
these things are tiny. What could be the problem
with scaling this up to a bigger scale?

It feels like so mechanically
complex and flimsy. Could be flimsy.

That's one. There's another one. I mean, the thing
about these Harvestmen is that they don't
weigh anything.

If you have a long
beam, your beam strength

goes as length squared, but
your mass goes as length cubed. So there's a good
reason that we don't

see dog or horse sized
spiders galloping around, which is maybe just as well.

But one other interesting
point I wanted to make, and I'm showing it here, is
that you talked about flimsy.

They are flimsy and
bending, but they can be pretty strong in intention. So this is one of these
harvestmen in a windstorm.

And you can see what it's done. It's flattened itself,
spread eagled on the wall and loaded itself in tension,
because the legs are quite
a bit stronger in tension. Still, scaling is an issue.

But what if gravity
was no problem. What if you were
supported by water. Could you get much bigger
with the same form factor?

Well, yes, you could. These are the
Japanese spider crabs, and now we're starting to get
into Reachbot-like proportions.

Fortunately, there is
another technology out there. If I wanted to
have something that is much simpler than a
long multi-jointed leg,

could I do something else? Could I have a
different kind of limb that I can reach a
very long distance

and grab things without
having a long and complicated multi-jointed leg?

And we literally did use these
for our first prototypes. There are better ones out there.

They're used for booms, for
antennas and space, for example,

and some other applications,
which we can talk about later, but that's the basic idea. So instead of a very
long, somewhat complicated

multi-jointed limb,
let's just have one of these extending space booms.

Another idea,
principle number 2 is that these things they're weak
and bending and in torsion,

but they're strong in tension. So if I have a bunch
of them going out

in different directions, and
if I have grippers on the end and I can pull, I can
actually pull quite hard.

I probably if I would
clamp this to the ceiling, I could probably hang my
whole weight from this tape

without breaking it. So this idea of
suspending yourself with long limbs and secure
grasps at the periphery

is also not entirely a new idea. Here's an orangutan that's
demonstrating it nicely.

So suppose we do that. We say we're going to have
a small body with really long limbs.

When I do that, what
happens is that I start to turn legged locomotion
into a manipulation problem,

like multiple fingers
manipulating a body. And this is something that has
been studied for many years.

It was actually part of
what I did for my own PhD. You have multiple fingers
pressing on a body.

I can talk about grasp force
and force closure and things like that. The difference is
that now, instead

of having fingers that
press upon a body, I have these long limbs
that pull upon the body.

So I just invert the sign. And I can still talk about
things like grasp quality

and force closure and so on. Each arm has three
joints that are powered

at the base for pan and
tilt and one for extension, and then I have a
gripper at the end.

And the one thing
that is different, though, from the classic
grasping problem, is that I'm not dealing
with frictional contacts.

So friction is if you press
your finger on something and it slips, I'm now
actually grasping.

So I have a different set of
contact constraints at the tip, but I want to spend a little
bit of time talking about that.

So we want to grasp
onto rocky surfaces. How shall we do that? We know how to do that.

We like to use microspines. We actually did it way
back when on a project with Boston Dynamics.

This was the rise robot,
and we did it with LEMUR and we've done it
with other things,

and there's a whole theory
of spine surface interaction.

What it comes down to
this is this-- you, for a given spine of
a given sharpness,

and depending on how
rough the surface is, you can predict how many
what we call asperities,

little bumps or pits on the
surface that it will find where it can latch on and get a grip.

And then how much
force you can apply. Actually, it depends on
the angle of the spine.

It also depends on the
local surface inclination and on friction.

We have very good models of it. The predictions from the
models match reality very well,

but there's a lot of scatter. So this means you really have
to-- if you're planning out

grasps, you really have to do
kind of a stochastic analysis.

So let's put it all together. We need a gripper that
will grab rocky surfaces.

So we start out with our spines
and our models of spine force contact.

We have fingers on the gripper. The gripper grabs onto surfaces,
the spines make contact.

And what we do is we apply
a load force to the gripper. Knowing that I can compute
what the force should

be at each finger, and I can
compute whether each finger would either slip or detach.

And what we then
do is we start out with a given pulling direction. We gradually increase
the force until a limit

is exceeded somewhere. And when it is,
that's one data point. And if we just keep doing
that over all possible pulling

directions, we build what
we call a limit surface. And let me show you that
in just the next slide.

So we pull and there we go. So it's a Monte
Carlo simulation. We simulate over the
range of possible pulling

angles for each
part of the surface, we solve for contact
forces, we check failure.

If it didn't fail, we keep
pulling harder until it does, and we get one point
on our limit surface.

And in the end, the limit
surface looks like this. It's a convex surface
in four-space.

So this is a plot in Fx, y,
and z embed a coordinate system

on the hand, x, y, z. And I pull in
different directions. And any force vector
that is inside

this limit surface should
be sustained-- in theory, should be sustained
by the grasp.

And you might wonder, what are
these funny square facets here? That corresponds to a
different failure mode

where instead of slipping on the
surface, I pull it in such a way that one of the fingers
would actually detach.

If you take a cross-section
of this limit surface, it looks like this.

Remember I said
it was stochastic. So the mean is in
the blue and then one standard
deviation is in red.

like that brown
arrow there, and I'm looking to see whether it
will be inside the limit

surface which is good, or if it
will intersect it, which is bad.

Before I move on, let me stop
and take any questions on this because I want to move on to
other topics in a few minutes.

[INAUDIBLE] pretty impressive. Do you obtain this limit
service by modeling or by experimental data?

By both. So you can build
it up empirically by pulling in
different directions,

although that takes a long time. So what we usually do
is we do it by modeling. So, yeah, it's a great
question, actually.
So let me go back a bit.

So given a gripper
design with however many fingers say 3 and
given some known compliance

in the fingers, if
I pull at the wrist, then it's a well-posed problem.

I can compute what the force
should be at every finger. And then for each finger,
however many spines it has

and how rough the
surface is and so on, I can compute what is
the probability that it

will sustain that contact,
or else that it will fail. And then I add it up
for all the fingers

and I can generate
numerically one point. And so that's what we do by
the Monte Carlo simulation.

I don't know if I
have a slide of it,

but this limit
surface is generated numerically through the
Monte Carlo simulation.

But then what we usually do
is we'll do a number of points and we hope to see them
fit on the surface.

There's actually a different
paper for science robotics where we build one
of these surfaces and then you see some
discrete empirical points

that lie on the surface. I see it's very
interesting because when you think about the
individual hawks, some of them

can give you a very good
contact normal direction. So, technically, if all of
those contact points are rigid,

you will have like a
forced [INAUDIBLE]. And [INAUDIBLE] service can
technically be infinity.

Well, no, because-- it's a
really good point though.

No, because if I pull too hard,
the spine itself will fail.

And, furthermore, we
avoid doing too much

of this kind of
testing where we look at the absolute limit to
failure on spines on rough rock

and then comparing it
empirically for failure because failure is actually
hard on the spines.

Even if we don't
break the spine, if they slip at high load,
we tend to dull the points.

And so what we're more likely
to do is go for a safe 90% thing

and verify that it has
the right shape and all. Another point that you're kind
of alluding to, which I didn't--

I cut it out for time,
is that we don't have one spine per finger. Not with this gripper we need.

We need to carry
a lot of weight. So we want to do-- we want an array of spines.

But that brings up this
problem of load sharing. If I have, let's say, 10 spines
on a finger and I make contact

and I pull,
unfortunately, because of this stochastic nature,
what's going to happen is that one or two of them
will make contact first,

and then the other
ones are doing nothing. So I need to have
some local compliance

so that it conforms
and it spreads the load not perfectly,
but more or less

evenly among all the spines. You can do it visually, but we
also have used a tally surf.

Anyway, the short answer is
you can do it multiple ways. If you go to a good metrology
place, like a machine shop,

they'll have a tally server. You could do it that way. We've done it that way. Works real well. You can also get a
reasonable estimate visually.

Also laser micrometer, if you
have a good one, works nicely. Yeah, we've used all of those.

And we're not trying to get
super accurate roughness data.

What I want to
know is basically, are these spines sharp enough
that I have a good chance

of getting a grip?  Let me just say a couple more
things about this limit surface

stuff. One is, as you can see in the
top plot, what I'm-- again,

this is a cross-section
of the 3D limit surface. And what am I doing? I'm looking for different
values of internal grasp force,

so I'm squeezing a little bit. Three newtons is less
than a pound 6 newtons

a little more than a pound
9 newtons 12 newtons. So it's like grasp
and squeeze harder. Not surprisingly,
my limit surface
is growing almost linearly. This gets back to your question.

What if I have more
or less spines? If I only have 10 spines. I'm on this inner red plot here.

And if I go to orange, I
have 20, 30, 40 spines.

That's good. I have more spines. I can take more
load, but you can see I'm getting
diminishing returns.

And maybe you can guess why I'm
getting diminishing returns. In other words, 50 is
not much better than 40,

but 40 is a lot better than 10. [INAUDIBLE] it's
harder to distribute.

Yeah, because I'm getting
less and less good at getting uniform distribution.

That's exactly right. That's the problem. And so you hear that-- you
see where adding more spines is good, but after a point it
really isn't getting any better.
Any other questions? These are good ones.

No, all right. I'll move on a bit, I guess. Oh, yeah. Go ahead. There was one, two
all of a sudden.

Just here it's not
symmetric because what you're grasping onto is not--

The grasp is not symmetric. Yes. So if I did a symmetric grasp
on a perfect hemisphere,
it should be symmetric. And there was 1 over there. Yeah. Are lava tubes on Mars?

Did they provide really
a solid footing-- We don't know.

We have never been in

like Mathieu suggests--

I mean, they think
our best guess is that the ones in

Now, the good news is that

So [INAUDIBLE] that's an

Other questions? That's great.  No, I guess I can move on a bit.

Other things we learned. I'm now making segueing into
talking a little bit about how

you choose a good grasp. So all things because-- yeah, and this is
where-- this robot
is very different from LEMUR. LEMUR's climbing up the wall. It doesn't have very much reach.

And, therefore,
it has to make do with whatever the best
grasp it is that it can

find within its small reach. We have the possibility to
choose like, oh, look up there.

That looks like a really
good grass spot right there. And so we want to know
what's a good grasp spot.

Well, one of the things
that helps a whole lot is if it's a convex shape. So we like ridges, we like
knob-like, dome-like features,

which is not-- if there's
anybody here done any kind of climbing on like
a climbing wall or-- a show of hands.

One person, two or
three, admit it. Yeah, I mean, you
have some already, some intuition about
what's a good grasp.

What we're plotting here. This angle alpha is
essentially a measure

of how well we're wrapping
around and conforming to the surface. And blue, which is
0, is the worst case.

That means I had
to take my hand, open it all the way
as wide as I could, and go on to a dead
flat surface and pull.

Well, I only have three fingers. Go on a dead flat
surface and pull. And I can pull out a
little bit, but not a lot.

By the way, when we're climbing
vertical buildings or cinder walls or things,
that's where we are.

We're on we're in that regime. On the other hand, if
it's a little bit rounded, things start to
get better rapidly.

And what I'm plotting
here is, again, it's the ratio of pull force to grasp
force as a function of my grasp

force. So working up in this area
is a really nice place to be. It's very effective,
which means it really

is worthwhile to try
to identify things that would be a good place to grasp. So that's another
interesting question.

How might I do that? Any thoughts? It's got to be some

Just look. [LAUGHTER]

You just ask a large

A couple of
interesting things also that we thought about
is we did all this, how many degrees of
freedom, if I go up there,

how many degrees of freedom
do I need to actually conform to the surfaces? And, remember, when we're
talking about conformation

at multiple length
scales, I need to get--

we've already been
talking ad nauseam about grasping with
microspines at the kind of microscopic scale,
a millimeter or so.

Well, the next one that
is really of interest is, how long should
my fingers be and how many joints
should they be.

Do I need long spidery fingers? And do they need two knuckles
or three or four or whatever?

And then, finally, how big
the gripper itself should be, because that's going to
dictate what's a good site.

So we did a study where we
looked at that kinematically, and we looked at
fingers with 1, 2, 3, 4,

up to 5 degrees of freedom. Now before we freak out,
that doesn't mean they all have to be actuated. They could be passive.

They could be passively
compliant degrees of freedom. But the question we
were interested in is, how much
difference does this--

do these additional
degrees of freedom-- so here I have a bend joint. The spines on their
little spine module

can move back and
forth a little bit. How much advantage
am I really getting from these additional
degrees of freedom?

And the answer is
actually quite a bit. What the plots on
the right show, each color is essentially
showing the additional area

on a rock feature
that I can grab by virtue of the additional
degrees of freedom.

So we did actually go
for this bottom solution. And the gripper looks like this.

It's not a gripper you'd
want to use to manipulate. It is really a gripper
just for grabbing.

And it has just one motor
and a huge system of tendons

and what are called
differentials for distributing the degrees of freedom.

Let me say a bit about that. It's not a new idea. This has been around
for thousands of years. If you have a team
of horses or oxen

and you want them
all to pull a wagon, you don't want whichever
one of your horses or oxen

gets a little bit
ahead of the others to wind up taking all the load. You want to make sure
that they share it evenly.

So you make this thing that
looks kind of a Calder mobile that ensures that all your
draft animals experience exactly

the same fraction of the load,
even if one's a little bit ahead of the other. And it's been around
since at least Roman

times as a known solution. So that's what we use. We have one tendon
for each finger.

They're all connected
to this motor. They run through this
differential system. They run down.

You can see the bending degrees
of freedom in the finger here. And you can see that the
spines are arrayed in a tile,

and the tile can slide
back and forth that way, and it can also rock side to
side so that, essentially, this

is a gripper that you can
just let it glom onto a rock and then start tightening it and
be reasonably confident that all

the spines are getting a
somewhat uniform grasping force. And I won't go into detail
here, but there's a lot more

in the science robotics paper. There, by the way, up
in the right corner is the whiffle tree, so-called.

It really basically
exactly the same as what you see for draft animals. Any question on this
before I move on for those

who are into design? Yeah. So I don't know if this is
the right time to ask this, but I know when
you go to the moon,

you have to deal
with lunar regolith. Do you have to deal with
Martian regolith getting in the way of these things. No, well, first of all,
there is less on Mars.

And secondly, when
you're in a lava tube, actually, one of
the big hopes is that there really won't there
will be some on the floor.

But we're going to be grabbing
walls and ceilings especially. So the answer is we don't
know but we hope not.

A little bit of dust
is not a problem. Several millimeters of dust
is not really a problem.

On the other hand, if it's
several centimeters of dust, then it is a problem. Yeah. [INAUDIBLE]

Yeah. So this kind of load
sharing mechanism works on--

what works for different
limbs, different fingers, or for every individual--

It's different levels. So the load sharing
among individual spines

is just compliance. And it's imperfect, which is why
we get diminishing returns as we go from 30 to 40 to 50 spines.

Then the load sharing
among the fingers is this differential system.

And these are all
just design choices that were somewhat empirically
determined that this
works well enough.  Good questions.

So one of the things
we realized early on is that the perception
of the surface

is really a two-stage problem. From the body of
the robot, I want

to know where is a good grasp. And I actually want to know that
before I extend the limb all

the way out, because it
turns out that by the time you've extended a limb out,
let's say ultimately 10 meters

or so, you've made a fairly
large commitment about where you're going.

And so you'd like
to know that you're

aiming at a macroscopic
scale, at a place that looks like it's going to
have a graspable feature.

And then as you get
closer, now you really want to know where
exactly do I want to grip.

So we're using both
distant and near sensing.

The nearest sensing is
in the millimeter range, and that's how we're
choosing our grasp sites.

The other thing
to be aware of is that if you've got this gripper
all the way out there, I mean, our positioning accuracy
is, frankly, not very good.

So one of the things we learned
with an early planar prototype is that we really have to
use a camera to look at that
and do some visual guidance. So the near-surface scanning.

So this is a typical
result of what happens in this case to be a
rather good graspable feature.
So May 2023.

And we didn't really

So we have one Reachbot

yeah.

So how would this
thing play out? Well, you would need-- if you want to really use the
booms primarily in tension,

you need a lot of them. In fact, the grasp theory
says that if you've got fingers that can
only push but not pull,

or if you've got booms that can
only pull but not push, then for a system in n degrees of
freedom, you need n plus 1

for full force closure. So that means for
a guaranteed stable grasp where I'm always
pulling on the booms

and I'm only relying on
their tensile strength, I need n plus 1, which in
this case would be how many?

Seven. Seven. Right. 6 degrees of freedom plus 1. Is that good? No, I need one more because
I still need to walk.

So I need to be able to

to eight, which

is why you get this

But it leads to interesting
problems in motion planning. This was mostly the work of
Marcos' student Stephanie

Schneider. The idea is you identify
candidate grasp sites,

you know where your body is now,
you know where you want to go, you need to do that
in a way that you

satisfy all the kinematic
and joint angle restriction constraints. And then if you're
going to optimize,

you'd like it to
be safe and you'd like it to move as
little as possible.

And what else would
we maybe to optimize?

There's one that
I didn't mention, which actually turns
out to be important.

Grasp stability. I want to make sure that as I
get from one place to another,

that at all times I maintain
a highly stable and reasonably stiff grasp.

So there it is doing

where you really push the

If you really do have a gripper
that's only held by strings,

you are more sensitive to
